Posts.Content: Mar 8, 2009 08:24PM DFOnt wrote: I finished 25 rad treatments on Feb. 11.  I had 3 Fec and 3 Taxotere chemos, last one on Dec. 6. I really didn't have any fatigue during or after radiation.  I had 1 month between my last chemo and radiation. Started taking Tamoxifen about 2 weeks ago, no issues from that either so far.
Posts.Title: RADIATION FATIGUE - POLL bluejay1 Siciliana

Posts.Content: Nov 15, 2008 09:04PM DFOnt wrote: I had my hair cut shorter a few weeks before starting chemo.  I had intended to shave it when it started coming out.  Mine didn't come out in clumps though, it was just coming out in strands so I left it, I was curious to see how much would actually come out on it's own. I liked having some hair stick out from under a hat, I still had bangs.  I just shaved the rest off about a week ago, and I had my 5th chemo on Friday.  I still left a little in the front, just seemed weird to shave it all off.  I've just started wearing a wig occasionally.  I feel more comfortable in hats, I have a few of the Cozy Caps from Headcovers.com and that's what I usually wear.
Posts.Title: when did you shave your head? mela4409 goldie0827

Posts.Content: DFOnt wrote: I had my first of 3 FEC treatments on Aug. 22.  It wasn't too bad.  I have 2 more every 3 weeks, then Taxotere for 3 treatments every 3 weeks.  Those of you that have had multiple FEC treatments, have you found the side effects got worse after more treatments or about the same? Anybody have this same protocol already? Did you find the Taxotere worse than FEC?   Deirdre Deirdre: Treatment - June 2008 mastectomy, 3 FEC, 3 Taxotere, Radiation, Tamoxifen, Sept 2012 Unilateral Diep flap reconstruction Dx 6/2008, IDC, 1cm, Stage IIA, 1/9 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: FEC? DFOnt IrishTwin

Posts.Content: Aug 30, 2008 09:31AM DFOnt wrote: HI Tanz I just came on looking for anyone else with a picc, they don't seem too common on here. I have a picc line.  I started FEC chemo on Aug 22 and had the picc inserted a week before. The insertion wasn't bad.  The nurse froze the site then used an ultrasound to guide it through the vein, then did an x-ray to make sure it was in the right place.  It wasn't too uncomfortable, I think the worst part was the needle to freeze the site.  Mine took a while because they had problems getting the xray machine to turn on.  I did overdo it that day though!  I couldn't feel it because it was frozen and went shopping afterwards!  Carrying bags etc.  When I got home I noticed quite a bit of blood on the guaze around it.  Homecare nurse came the next morning to change the dressing.  Then the nurse changed it a week later when I went to get bloodwork for chemo.  Homecare nurse comes once a week when I'm not having chemo to flush it and change the dressing.  Mine is above my elbow.  I have been using a piece of a knee high stocking (cotton blend) to cover it so I don't get it caught on stuff, plus it's wrapped in gauze and taped to my arm.  The worst part is having a shower.  I have my husband help wrap it in saran wrap but it's a pain in the butt.  Have to keep it dry.  I've seen a couple of gadgets online to cover it with, maybe I'll order one.  I actually had my first bath with it in today, I covered it with one of my daughter's waterproof swim diaper covers!   I don't know what Bueller is, I just found this post by searching for picc. All the nurses have said it is the "way to go".  I just wanted to avoid repeated needle pricks. Also can't have blood pressure taken on that arm.  Can't have it on my other arm either because I had a mastectomy on that side.  I also bought some tops with longer sleeves to cover it. Best of luck with it! Deirdre
Posts.Title: Bueller? Anyone? Tanzie badboob67
